metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State (Advocate-General of Madhya Pradesh)

facts.text: Advocate-General of Madhya Pradesh filed complaint on January 13, 1953 against appellant and three others under s.282 of Indian Companies Act and ss.465 and 477A of Indian Penal Code.
Proceedings commenced in 1954 before a Magistrate.
Proceedings transferred on May 18, 1955 to Special Magistrate Shri K. L. Pandey at Nagpur in Criminal Case No. I of 1955.
Special Magistrate commenced recording of evidence on July 4, 1955.
Criminal Procedure Code Amendment Act 26 of 1955 received assent of President on August 12, 1955 and came into force on January 2, 1956.
Appellant made application on January 14, 1956 to Special Magistrate claiming right to appear as witness under s.342A of amended Code.
Special Magistrate dismissed appellant's application on February 2, 1956.
Appellant filed revision (Criminal Revision No. 150 of 1956) to High Court of Nagpur, dismissed on May 28, 1956.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of s.342A of the amended CrPC (inserted by s.61 of Amending Act 26 of 1955) apply to pending prosecution where recording of evidence commenced prior to commencement of the Amending Act on January 2, 1956, particularly in light of s.116 of the Amending Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant entitled to appear as witness under s.342A of amended Code in disproof of charges.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.342A CrPC (as amended); general principle that procedural amendments apply retrospectively

respondent_arguments.text: Proceedings pending before Special Magistrate to continue as per unamended Code; s.342A not applicable as per s.116(c) of Amending Act, which states such inquiries/trials shall be continued 'as if this Act had not been passed'.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.116(c) CrPC Amending Act; wording of clause (c)

court_reasoning.text: No vested right in procedure; changes in procedure operate retrospectively unless expressly excluded. s.116 excludes specific sections (like 4(w), 207A, 251A, 260) for cases where evidence recording started before commencement, but s.342A (in Chapter 24) not excluded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interpretation of s.116 avoids conflict between clauses and concluding portion; s.342A applies to pending proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in construing clause (c) too broadly to exclude entire Act; only specified provisions excluded.

Under unamended Code, accused could not appear as witness (s.342, s.118 Evidence Act inapplicable); Art.20(3) Constitution protects against self-incrimination; s.342A makes accused competent witness at own request.

holdings.text: s.342A of amended CrPC applies to pending trials before Magistrate where evidence recording commenced prior to Amending Act's commencement, as not expressly excluded by s.116.
Appellant is competent witness for defence and entitled to give evidence on oath in disproof of charges.

precedents_cited.case_name: Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving
precedents_cited.relevance: No vested right in procedure; procedural changes operate retrospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure (as amended by Act 26 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: s.342A makes accused competent witness; s.116 governs applicability to pending proceedings, excluding specific provisions only.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Under unamended law, accused incompetent to testify.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No accused compelled to be witness against himself.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of Special Magistrate and Nagpur High Court set aside. Appellant held entitled to appear as competent witness under s.342A CrPC.
outcome.relief_granted: Appellant permitted to give evidence as witness in disproof of charges.

key_quotes.text: No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes retrospective effect of procedural amendments.

key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability of amended provision.

key_quotes.text: The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled... as a competent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly reverses lower courts and grants relief.
